name: Android Study Jam Kickoff Party
description:
Hello everyone! Join us at 5:30 PM for food and networking. At 6:00 PM, we'll get the Jam Party feed from Google and kick off the event. 

Learn the basics of Android and Java programming, and take the first step on your journey to becoming an Android developer. Built by Google.  

Update: Time has been officially announced. I apologize to everyone who already RSVP'd and I hope that everyone can still make it!

Please tell your friends and join us. Look forward to exciting announcements and opportunities to win prizes. 

Food: We plan to have Balance Grille food delivered for our supper! 

This kickoff will welcome us and announce the app development challenge. Bring a device to sign up or do it at home after the event. We will find out more at the event! Cheers!

name: Android Open Hack
description:
Let's meet and learn about Android development. We will schedule to use Seed Coworking again. 

Please visit the Discussion's board to find Dorene's list of great links she captured while at the Kickoff Meetup.

name: StudyJamDev / Open Hack
description:
The Google Developer Group Toledo welcomes you to participate in an Open Hack night. Our Study Jam Dev is for anyone who would like to work on their Android coursework and projects. 

The hashtag for the event is: #DevStudyJam 

If you are from the community and would like work on anything you are welcome to attend our dual track Open Hack Night. Please register on this GDG Toledo Open Hack Meetup Site, thanks for joining us.

The hashtag for the event is: #DevStudyJam 

If you are from the community and would like work on anything you are welcome to attend our dual track Open Hack Night. Please register on this GDG Toledo Open Hack Meetup Site, thanks for joining us.

description:
The Google Developer Group Toledo welcomes you to participate in an Open Hack night. Our Study Jam Dev is for anyone who would like to work on their Android coursework and projects. 

The hashtag for the event is: #DevStudyJam 

If you are from the tech community and would like work on anything you are welcome to attend our dual track Open Hack Night. Please register on this GDG Toledo Open Hack Meetup Site, thanks for joining us.

name: Road Trip to Detroit DevFest!
description:
Join us for a full day of excellent presentations on Android and Google Web/Cloud technologies in the heart of downtown Detroit! More information can be found at the Michigan Devfest website conveniently located at : http://michigandevfest.com/

Let's meet at Eye Glass World off Monroe near the intersection of Secor and Monroe Streets. https://goo.gl/maps/WfbriUUUEu32

name: Google IO Extended
description: Yes, we're holding it one week after the main I/O event, but with a huge bonus: you will be able to ask +James Tamplin, co-founder of #Firebase and +Magnus Hyttsten, Developer Advocate questions about Firebase LIVE! Make sure to start posting your questions today with #AskFirebaseLive. Register at bit.ly/registerLH now!. Along the way, we'll have fun, and share stories about our favorite elements that were unveiled at I/O. It'll be great--so come out and join us!﻿

name: Firebase Talk with our guest Dave Koziol
description:
Ladies and gentlemen,

We have our guest Dave Koziol who is coming to be our guest speaker to discuss Firebase usage. Once again Don has been the hero and is letting us meet up at Seed Coworking.  There is a MudHens game scheduled the same night (7pm) so parking might be difficult if you don't get there on time. And trust me, you don't want to miss this meetup. 

For those of you who don't know what Firebase is, it was founded in 2011 and is a cloud services provider and backend as a service.  They offer realtime database, storage, analytics, cloud messaging, authentication and more for Android, IOS and web applications. They were purchased by Google in 2014 and at Google IO their updated services.  So come and join us to see one of the best options to Parse that is available!

name: GDG Open Hack
description: Monthly open hack night to work on whatever projects you would like community assistance with. Come code with friends.

name: Holiday Mixer 2016 | Geek Dinner
description:
Google Developer Group & Tech Toledo invites all GDG'ers to join us on December 8th for the 6th Annual Geek Dinner Holiday Mixer. This is the largest social gathering of IT professionals in the Toledo region.

FREE to attend! 

RSVP at Eventbrite. Members of regional IT groups will be in attendance, holding their annual end-of-year Geek Dinners with us. Attendees are responsible for paying for their own drinks and food. At the mixer, you can meet colleagues, learn about each group, get a recap of what happened in 2016, and start to plan for 2017.

Some of the invited user groups, professional organizations, and meet-ups are:

Toledo Web Professionals
Google Developer Group Toledo
OpenHack Toledo
TNewTech
Findlay Developers
Findlay Area dot net User Group
WordPress Toledo
Girl Develop It Toledo
Lean User Experience
ISACA Northwest Ohio
UT ACM student chapter
BGSU ACM student chapter
IEEE Toledo 

You are NOT required to be a member of any of these groups to attend. In fact, we welcome non-IT professionals who want to “geek out” with us, such as entrepreneurs, designers, business leaders, engineers, government officials, and marketing professionals. Feel free to invite your friends to this event on Facebook.

Your company can sponsor the Mixer to support the community! For $200, you will be recognized as an event sponsor and get a chance to share with the group why you chose to be a sponsor. Purchase a “sponsor ticket” at Eventbrite, contact Tech Toledo (link below), or simply send me a message here on Meetup.

I hope to see you all there!

Eventbrite: https://www.eventbrite.com/e/tech-toledo-holiday-mixer-2016-tickets-28627135533 

Tech Toledo Contact: http://techtoledo.com/contact-us/

name: Google Developer Group Dinner
description: A GDG dinner where we can all hang out and get to know each other without a laptop between us. Unfortunately at the moment, this isn't a Google sponsored event so you will have to pay for your own food. We are looking to see if there might be a surprise or two though. We are going to get to know all of you.

name: Android Beacons
description:
This talk is an introduction to beacon technologies for Android devices. We'll look at what types of beacons are out there to use, such as RadBeacons and Estimotes. We'll also discuss the different types of beacon protocols available to those beacons: Eddystone and AltBeacon. We'll walk through exactly how each of these protocols work and how to implement them into your application using either Google's Proximity Beacon API coupled with Nearby Messages API and also with the AltBeacon library. So join us for the ins and outs of beacons on Android to better your user's location and proximity experiences. 

About Speaker

Jake VanAssche is a Software Engineer at Arbormoon Software Inc. focusing on developing Android mobile applications. He recently got his Master's degree in Computer Science from Wayne State and has a Bachelor's degree in Software Engineering from the University of Detroit Mercy.

name: So You Want to be an Android Developer
description:
Have you dreamed of developing your own app, but didn't know how to get started? We'll go over getting started with Android development and leave you with a few simple steps to build your first app (app idea not included).

Chris Wammes is a Applications Development Supervisor at Bowling Green State University. His focus at BGSU is on all areas of the web and includes, web content management, enterprise portal, calendar, digital asset management, digital signage, custom web development and mobile. He also helps run Toledo Web Professionals, and developed the Toledo Tech Events Android app.

Good News everyone! We have a new sponsor for this event! Vitamin T from Royal Oak, Michigan has agreed to sponsor our food, yeah! 

https://vitamintalent.com/talent/

Vitamin T connects companies with creative and marketing talent who have the skills and experience they need. We support the growth of the creative industry by investing in meaningful ways that improve the lives of our customers and talent.

name: Roadtrip to the Michigan DevFest
description:
Toledo Googlers,

The Detroit and Ann Arbor Chapters of the Google Developers Group (GDG) are proud to host the Fifth Annual Michigan Google Developers DevFest on Saturday, kicking off at 9:00 AM, April 22, 2017 in Downtown Detroit. 

We will be taking a trip up to experience it first hand. If you would like to go, purchase tickets as soon as you can to get the early discount before prices rise. (Purchase tickets here).

As you might have noticed in a recent announcement, early bird prices dropped $10 for professional attendees. Now get your seat for $50. That is huge. Don't miss this deal! 

This is the best conference you'll attend this year for Google (unless you are going to Google/IO, you lucky duck). 

https://devfest2017-8f458.firebaseapp.com/

To join the carpool, meet us at the parking lot east of Eyeglasses World. We plan to share the ride and carpool to the event.

name: Connect IT & Geek Dinner
description:
It's that time again! The weather is becoming beautiful, and it's the perfect time for us to get together and discuss our summer plans as a group. Come join us for a great meal and great socialization time. This is the perfect time to express what you joined the GDG for to help us make sure we align with expectations.

*****Update*****

There has been a change in plans!! Keith Instone has alerted us to another event occurring in the same day. So we will be joining them at Connect IT!

Feel free to register at the their website listed directly below.

https://toledoohcoc.wliinc19.com/events/Connect-IT-Bringing-Together-Information-Technology-Professionals-in-the-Toledo-Region-1621/register

name: Strategies for Learning React
description:
GDG Toledo Welcomes Ryan Lanciaux! 

React has been on your radar for some time but you don't know the best way to dive in to the ecosystem. There are so many awesome libraries but it's hard to distinguish between what's necessary and what's addressing a pain-point you don't yet have.

In this talk, we will consider some strategies for learning React and some of React's core principles. From there, we will discuss how taking a component-based view of our front-end can help us build an application architecture that scales over time. Finally, we'll examine some important libraries in the React ecosystem and what problems they are working to solve.

Ryan Lanciaux is a professional software developer in Ann Arbor, MI. Although he programs in several languages, his current area of focus is front-end development. Ryan attempts to contribute to the development community through his (often neglected) blog.

We're teaming up with CocoaHeads this month! 

Food provided by GroundSpeed!

name: Geek Dinner
description:
Due to the lack of people going tonight, we are going to postpone this meeting until a later date. I wanted to make sure that everyone was aware just in case someone not registered decided to show up. Enjoy your evening everyone!

The weather is becoming beautiful, and it's once again time for us to get together and discuss our vision as a group. Come join us for a great meal and great socialization time. This is the perfect time to express what you joined the GDG for to help us make sure we align with expectations.

name: Building Your Own Collaborative Editing Web Forms For Free
description:
Guest Speaker: David Johnson

Have your business users ever said, "we have this Excel form that we need to turn into a web form"? So you, as a full-stack web developer, turn it into a HTML form with an AJAX POST to save the data to a database table in the standard CRUD model. It works well enough, but then the users said, "we really need simultaneous editing for everyone in the office." Now you're in trouble because you're trying to reinvent Google Docs / Sheets, which are very complex. How do those collaborative editing tools really work? 

We will look at the Google Realtime API, which uses Operational Transformation to automatically synchronize a document between multiple simultaneous editors. Everything you know about distributed version control systems applies to this situation, but now you need to make it work seamlessly for users who have never heard of "git rebase". The client and server implementation of Operational Transformation is very challenging.

Alternatives to Operational Transformation (OT) include Differential Synchronization (DS, aka. 3-way merge), Conflict-free Replicated Data Type (CRDT), and plain old Last Write Wins (LWW). For any of these methods, the critical elements include websockets, message queues, and persistent data storage. This presentation will include a demonstration of a simple implementation of collaborative editing with free, locally hosted software only.

name: Tech Toledo's Holiday Mixer 2017
description:
• What we'll do

It appears as tickets have more sold out. But everyone is welcome to join at 8 pm upstairs on the roof (The Heights) for the social gathering and drinks (bring your money and possibly your Lyft app if you will be drinking a lot!)

Tech Toledo invites all information technology professionals to join us on Thursday December 7th for our 7th Annual Holiday Mixer. The Mixer is our end-of-the-year community party and a celebration of the various IT-related groups (meetups, professionals associations, user groups). We also welcome non-IT professionals, such as entrepreneurs, designers, business leaders, planners, engineers, government officials, and marketing professionals, to join us to meet members of the region's tech community. We are at the new Renaissance Toledo Downtown Hotel this year. The Mixer outgrew Packo's at the Park and the Blarney Event Center. Now we are at the newest hotel in downtown Toledo, with room for our largest crowd ever. The Mixer is free to attend, but individuals should register for a ticket here ahead of time. There will be a cash bar, as usual. New this year: we will be providing a light meal for attendees, thanks to our sponsors! Companies and organizations can sponsor the Mixer to support the community! Sponsors will be mentioned in promotional material before the event and on signage at the Mixer. Basic sponsorship is only $100. Advanced sponsorship is $200, for those organizations that want to give more. The $500 Premier sponsorship level includes a few minutes of speaking time and a table to display information. Sponsors can pay here with a credit card by selecting one of the sponsor "tickets." Or contact us via email ([masked]) to request an invoice. As in past years, community groups are invited to join us. Instead of having a separate "holiday party" for your group, have it with us! It is free for groups to join us. We just ask that the group leaders promote the Mixer, invite their members, and ask members to register here with us. In return, each group gets a table at the Mixer, where members can hang out and prospective members can learn more about the group. Complete the "Community group" ticket information to apply. See TechToledo.com for the current list of sponsors and community groups. After the Mixer, we encourage attendees who want to keep partying to join us at The Heights, the hotel's amazing rooftop bar. The Vistula Garage (across the street) provides convenient parking: take the underground concourse to the hotel. Tentative schedule 5:30pm: Doors open to the ballroom. If you show up early, you can hang out in the foyer or check out the hotel. 5:30pm - 6:30pm: Get some food and drink, visit sponsor tables, hang out with members of your group at their tables, or introduce yourself to someone new. 6:30pm - 7:15pm: Tech Toledo recap of what happened in 2017 and information about each community group. Brief sponsor presentations. 7:15pm - 8:00pm: Continue socializing, learning about the community groups, meeting sponsors, eating, drinking. 8:00pm: Event is over, head up to The Heights for more.

• What to bring
Members need to bring an appetite and the desire to mingle. Please RSVP ahead of time at : http://ttmixer2017.eventbrite.com/

• Important to know
how_to_find_us: Please RSVP as soon as possible. : http://ttmixer2017.eventbrite.com/

name: Google Cloud Study Jam
description:
Want to get started on the Google Cloud, but don't know where to begin?

Join us for our Cloud Study Jam! Together we'll work through three Google Cloud Platform Essentials labs, then you will get free access to the next quest so you can finish this series of labs at home to get a Google-hosted badge for your online profile. You will be able to get hands-on experience with Docker, Kubernetes and Scientific Data Processing, which will earn you additional badges.

Join this meetup to get official Google training, a $70+ value, free of charge.

Bring a laptop (PC, Mac or Chromebook)! The labs will run on all of the latest versions of the popular browsers. For the best experience, make sure your laptop has Firefox or Chrome installed.

Agenda:

11:00am: Three Google Cloud Platform Essentials labs

12:30pm: Break

1:00pm: Intro to Docker or Scientific Data Processing lab

2:00pm: Event ends

name: Build Actions for Your Community
description:
• What we'll do
Google-supported event to let developers learn how to build Apps for the Google Assistant that are useful for their community - whether it's a professional network, interest group, or their hometown.
The “Build Actions for Your Community” event is targeted at all levels of developers and we hope to see some great Actions on Google come out as a result and all of you having a ton of fun exploring what you can do with Google Assistant. We’ll provide you with content to learn how to create and actually build Actions on Google. They will be featured online and may even be showcased at the Google I/O Community Lounge.

• What to bring
Laptop

• Important to know

name: Material Design 2.0 with Flutter: An engaging user experience
description:
• What we'll do
Use and customize/brand the new Material Design Components (MDC), using Flutter to create a beautiful cross-platform mobile app (iOS & Android). There is also an intro to the Dart language for people familiar with Java.

• What to bring
Yourself and a laptop (optional).

• Important to know
Pizza, water, and limited developer swag will be provided.

name: Flutter: Beyond Hello World

venue.name: Brady Innovation Center, UT College of Engineering

description:
Join us for a guest lecture from Scott Stoll, co-owner of the Flutter study group and co-creator of the Flutter Zone podcast.

You can find Hello World and ListView tutorials all over the web. (In Flutter, they're pretty much the same thing.) But here we'll take a look at things on a little deeper level.

We'll look at how Flutter differs from other cross platform approaches such as React Native or Xamarin and how the new Dart 2.0 is practically tailor made for the Flutter framework. We'll look at the way Flutter's UI widgets code is structured, so it wont' look so strange and intimidating anymore. We'll talk about how you can unit test a UI in Flutter and then we can go over a few "Pitfalls and Brick Walls" that everyone seems to run into.

And along the way we can hopefully clear some commonly held misconceptions and a few wild rumors.
how_to_find_us: We're right inside the western side of the UT commercialization complex. Enter through Dorr St. or Douglas Ave.

name: Open code (come and work with your peers to create something great!)
description: Bring your laptop and an idea. We will be available for instructing how to setup your machine to create Flutter apps, Android, and anything else you might have questions about.

name: Tech Toledo Holiday Mixer
description:
Once again GDG Toledo will be joining the party with Tech Toledo during their holiday mixer.

"Tech Toledo invites members of the tech, design, and entrepreneur community to join us on Thursday December 6th for our 8th Annual Holiday Mixer.

The Mixer is our end-of-the-year community party and a celebration of the various tech-related groups (meetups, professionals associations, user groups). We welcome IT professionals, tech entrepreneurs, digital designers, business leaders, planners, engineers, government officials, marketing professionals, and anyone else interested in hanging out with the region’s tech community.

The Mixer is free for individuals to attend. You are responsible for paying for your own drinks. (Food is being catered and is covered) Individual registration is now open! Get your FREE ticket so we know you are coming. Tell us which community group you are with, if any."

Please sign up here: https://ttmixer2018.eventbrite.com/

We can't wait to see everyone there!

name: Tech Social
description:
We're going to do something different this month. Instead of having a particular topic or directed agenda, we'll be holding a social gathering at Backyard BBQ and just chatting about technology in general.

Some discussion starters might be:
What thing on the horizon interests you?
What don't you like about something that you regularly use?
What tech is missing that would benefit the area or people in general?
How do I find people/groups locally that would expand my network?
how_to_find_us: We'll be the group with the small GDG sign/paper standing on the table.
